results.title: Alzheimer's disease and other dementias: Diagnosis = Speaking from experience
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Speaking from experience”.
This Australian program presents a sensitive account of Alzheimer’s disease from the point of view of their families and carers. It looks at the early signs and behaviours, and the ways in which the patients and their carers handle diagnosis of the condition. The emotional impact this disease has on families is openly discussed, as well as practical advice given on how carers can best handle the progression of the condition.

results.title: Always was, always will be
results.creator_credit: SBS-TV, Madeline McGrady and Nick Power
results.brief_description: A documentary examining the fight by contemporary Aboriginal people, for land rights and for the recognition by white Australia that the British colonisation of this continent was illegal and has yet to be compensated for. Interviews with Aboriginal activists from the Northern Territory and New South Wales make it clear that while the government pays lip-service to the language of land rights, Aboriginal people have yet to receive full access to their land. Includes interviews with Pat Dodson, Marcia Langton and Michael Mansell.

results.title: Alvin Purple
results.brief_description: The Australian film revival did not begin with “Picnic at Hanging Rock” but with ocker comedy seen in “Stork”, “Barry McKenzie” and “Alvin Purple”. The latter remains one of the most profitable Australian films yet produced. Its popularity clearly reflected the moment - with the relaxation of censorship in the early seventies, a high spirited sex comedy in the Australian idiom had special appeal for Australian audiences. Alvin (Graeme Blundell) is an ordinary young man desiring a quiet life whose very ordinariness seems irresistible to women. The comedy is based on incongruity. Sex is rendered as slapstick. Jokes are at the expense of bastions of hypocrisy - psychiatry, the press and the law. The would-be recessive hero is the object of male sexual fantsy - sex without responsibility - a fantasy with which women could also apparently identify.

results.title: Alvar Aalto: technology and nature
results.creator_credit: Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten, WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.), BBC Wales and Ywe Yalander
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Born in Finland, Alvar Aalto (1898-1976) was one of the greatest architect and industrial designers of the 20th century. As a young man he rejected the ideals of art nouveau movement, preferring instead to follow his interests in functionalism. As a humanitarian he felt that democracy would be achieved by the mechanisation and standardisation of building practices, being the only way to give more to man. He also recognised the paradox of this and was to forever learn from nature, believing it to be the symbol of freedom. His architecture was widely accepted due to his success in marrying nature with art, man and mass production. But for Aalto, it was nature that was the great teacher, and nature that would provide the greatest inspiration to his work. Forever being influenced by the forests and nature broadly, his buildings would echo the elegance and asymmetry that expresses a natural order. Aalto’s humanitarian interests meant that the function of the building was always directed by the needs of the users. This earned Aalto lasting respect for his designs (i.e the Paimio Sanatorium has long been praised as one of the greatest buildings of the 20th Century), providing many humanitarian solutions to architectural problems. Aalto rejected synthetic materials and plastics, calling them, “drugstore architecture”, and preferred to use natural materials such as; wood, brick, stone, glass and ceramic tile. Aalto invested his interest in these materials and design to develop furniture and fittings to complete the interiors of his buildings. Aalto was most known in his industrial design for laminating and bending layers of birchwood to create bent wood furniture, a technique that has come to symbolise his home region.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Oy Yleisradio Ab Svenska TV-enheten, WNYC-TV (Television station : New York, N.Y.), BBC Wales and Ywe Yalander

results.title: Aluminium in the 80's: the Comalco story
results.creator_credit: Comalco, Terence McMahon Productions and Terence McMahon
results.brief_description: Gives an up-to-date account of the changing forces and the topical issues confronting Australia’s aluminium industry. It considers such topics as the economic benefits Australia will derive from an expanded aluminium industry; why power prices for smelters must be kept low; the extent to which Australia’s enormous coal resources will be devoted to this industry; why smelting is becoming more important than the export of raw bauxite; and the overall competitiveness of Australia’s aluminium industry. Suitable for middle and upper secondary levels.

results.title: Aluminium in Australia
results.creator_credit: Fraser Castle Productions, Norman Castle and Lilias Castle
results.brief_description: This film tells of the mining of bauxite deposits at Weipa in the far north of Australia - the York Peninsula. The product of this vast mining venture is then transported to Tasmania where it is processed into ingots at the Bell Bay Refinery. From ingots through the rolling mills it is processed into suitable form for the making of a variety of finished products for industry, the home and for commercial buildings. The enormous possibilities of the use of this light, versatile twentieth century metal are shown.

results.title: Aluminium from Mine to Metal
results.brief_description: Gives an overview of Alcoa’s main operations in Australia including the refining of bauxite to alumina in West Australia and the extraction of aluminium at Point Henry, Victoria.
